title: German submarine U-793
text:
U-793 was a <a href="German%20Type%20XVII%20submarine">Type XVIIA</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>. She was one of a small number of U-boats fitted with <a href="Hellmuth%20Walter">Hellmuth Walter</a>'s <a href="high%20test%20peroxide">high test peroxide</a> propulsion system, which offered a combination of <a href="air-independent%20propulsion">air-independent propulsion</a> and high submerged speeds. She spent the war as a trials vessel and was scuttled on 4 May 1945 in the Audorfer See, near <a href="Rendsburg">Rendsburg</a>.
Construction.
The "U-793" was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 1 December 1942 at the <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, as yard number 456. She was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 4 March 1944 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a>" Horst Heitz on 24 April 1944.
When she was completed, the submarine was long overall, with a beam of and a draught of . She was assessed at submerged. The submarine was powered by one <a href="Deutz%20AG">Deutz</a> SAA 8M517 <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> 8-cylinder <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a> producing a total of for use while surfaced and one Walter gas turbines producing a total of for use while submerged. She had one shaft and one <a href="propeller">propeller</a>. The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of using the HTP drive. When submerged, the <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> could operate for at on her HTP system and when surfaced, she could travel at .
The submarine was fitted with two <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (All fitted at the bow) and four <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of 12 men.
Service history.
"U-793" did not undertake any war patrols and was instead assigned as a trials boat at first to the <a href="5th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">5th U-boat Flotilla</a>, followed by the <a href="8th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">8th U-boat Flotilla</a>.
The "U-793" was scuttled on 4 May 1945 at 1.30am in the Audorfer See (<a href="Kaiser%20Wilhelm%20Canal">Kaiser Wilhelm Canal</a>), near <a href="Rendsburg">Rendsburg</a> during <a href="Operation%20Regenbogen%20%28U-boat%29">Operation Regenbogen</a>.
Wreck.
The wreck of "U-793" lay at until 26 May 1945, when she was lifted by the British and taken to the <a href="Howaldtswerke">Howaldtswerke</a> in <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> to be examined. She was first raised as a British prize and used for trials, but was soon torn down for parts and finally scrapped.
